properties.description:
River Otter

Find these playful creatures in the various lakes of Glenveagh

Freshwater Pearl Mussel

These endangered bivalves need clean water to survive. You can look but do not touch!

Curlew

Listen out for this wading bird's distinctive cur-leee call

Bog Cotton

A common sight in bogland, the sea of white can go as far as the eye can see

Irish Hare

One of Ireland's most iconic species, keep an eye out on your hikes up the mountains for this upland mammal

Heather

The bright purple flowers on this plant stand out on the open, rocky areas

Red Squirrel

Keep an eye out in the trees for this cute woodland creature

Red Deer

Ireland's largest mammal. Visit during the rut to see them in action

Pygmy Shrew

Ireland's smallest mammal. These tiny creatures might be hard to spot, keep your eyes peeled on the ground!

White-Tailed Bumblebee

An important pollinator species! bee populations are declining and need your help to survive

Lindenberg's Featherwort

This is one of two areas in the whole of Europe that this rare plant species can be seen

Red-Throated Diver

Glenveagh is one of the only places in Ireland that this bird breeds, usually preferring the colder North

Common Frog

The only species of frog in Ireland. Look anywhere wet and damp for these slimy creatures

Devil's Bit

This blue/purple plant looks a lot nicer than the name implies

Eurasian Bullfinch

This brightly coloured garden bird species is not to be missed. They are shy so keep an eye in the scrub and hedges

Birch Tree

The name sake of Glenveagh National Park. Identify this tree by its unmistakable white bark

Golden Eagle

Previously extinct in Ireland, this bird of prey has been reintroduced in Glenveagh and populations are growing

Irish Stoat

Found only in Ireland, this sub-species can be found in the long grasses or woodland

Long-eared Owl

This silent flying bird of prey can rotate its head 270 degrees!

Red Admiral Butterfly

This brightly coloured pollinator species brightens up any meadow
